QuestionGroup.Description: Compared to before, does the patient have the following problems?

Question.Name: AMNESIA~~Problems remembering things or events that happened recently~~~~Compared to before, does the patient have the following symptoms:~~ 1. Frequently misplacing his/her personal belongings?~~ 2. Forget how to carry out basic tasks? (such as turning off the lights/fan, making a drink, how to get assistance, etc) ~~ 3. Forget where he/she keeps his/her things?~~ 4. Forget what he/she has come to do?~~ 5. Have problems finding his/her way around?~~ 6. Ask repeated questions or repeat himself/herself often?

QuestionGroup.Description: Ask the patient these questions, a correct answer to each question scores one point.~~Start by asking the patient to remember a Memory Phrase (e.g. address “37 Bukit Timah Road”)

Question.Name: What is the year now?
What is the time to the nearest hour?
What is your age?
When is your date of birth?
What is your home address?
Where are we now?
What is my/his/her job? (Show an image to the patient if possible)
Count backwards from 20 to 1
Who is the country's current Prime minister?
Ask the patient to recall the Memory Phrase

QuestionGroup.Description: Compared to before, does the patient have the following problems?

Question.Name: APHASIA~~Disturbance of language function (receptive and/or expressive)~~~~Compared to before, does the patient have the following symptoms:~~ 1. Problems finding words to express his/herself in a conversation?~~ 2. Problems understanding what others say?~~ 3. Does the resident have problems naming objects or persons?

APRAXIA~~Impaired ability to execute motor activities despite intact motor abilities, sensory function and comprehension of the required task~~~~Compared to before, does the patient have the following symptoms:~~ 1. Problems performing familiar tasks or basic ADLs well? E.g. dressing, bathing~~ 2. Appear to be clumsier or appear to drop things more frequently?~~ 3. Problems using simple gadgets or appliances?

AGNOSIA~~Failure to recognise or identify objects despite intact sensory function~~~~Compared to before, does the patient have the following symptoms:~~ 1. Can’t recall or recognize familiar places?~~ 2. Have difficulties recognising the faces of people they know well? ~~ 3. Mistake familiar objects for something else? E.g. a toothbrush or comb for a shaver

EXECUTIVE DYSFUNCTION~~Impairment in ability to think abstractly, plan, initiate ,sequence, monitor and stop complex behaviour~~~~Compared to before, does the patient have the following symptoms:~~ 1. Does the resident have problems with simple math?~~ 2. Does the resident have problems initiating or performing his/her usual activities (iADLs) or planning what to do?~~ 3. Does the resident have problems getting started to do things~~ 4. Does the resident have problems controlling his/her behaviour?~~ 5. Does the resident have problems making decisions or making a choice?
Is there a significant decline in functioning as compared to previous level?
Is the course of the cognitive decline gradual? (i.e. More than 6 months)

QuestionGroup.Description: Does the patient have ANY of the following issues?

Question.Name: Signs of acute stroke eg.one-sided weakness, babinski’s sign
Recent head trauma with headache, loss of consciousness, vomiting (subdural hematoma)
Unexplained neurological symptoms eg. new onset of severe headaches or seizures
History of cancer, especially of a type or at a site associated with brain metastasis
Use of anticoagulants or history of bleeding disorder
History of urinary incontinence and gait disturbance early in the disease
Question.Symptom: Urinary incontinence and gait disturbance early

Question.Name: Acute onset of gait disturbance

QuestionGroup.Description: Does the patient have ANY of the following background medical issues?

Question.Name: Parkinson’s disease
Thyroid disorders
Vit B12 / Folate deficiency
Electrolyte imbalance – hypercalcemia, hyper/hyponatremia, advanced organ failure
Substance or drug induced condition
Psychiatric disorders – major depression, schzophrenia, acute delirium
